findings: LOW: Subtitle mentions 'Double-Spending Problem' before it has been introduced

frame_title: The Big Picture: Why This Matters
findings: LOW: 'Commodity Money' and 'Blockchain' appear on timeline without definitions yet
LOW: 'Coincidence of Wants' is economics jargon but is immediately explained in context

frame_title: Three Solutions to the Barter Problem
findings: MEDIUM: Three new concepts introduced simultaneously (commodity money, credit/IOUs, shared ledger); 'IOUs' not spelled out for students unfamiliar with the term
LOW: Three functions of money are standard economics terms but are clearly explained with examples
LOW: Uses \compactlist which may be a custom command not in standard beamer

frame_title: The Ledger: Humanity's Oldest Financial Technology

findings: MEDIUM: 'Immutability' is a technical term; brief plain-language gloss provided ('cannot be changed') but the word itself may intimidate no-prerequisite students
HIGH: Frame introduces account-based money, token-based money, bearer instrument concept, digital dilemma, and file-copy analogy -- more than 5 new ideas for a no-prerequisite audience

frame_title: The Traditional Solution: Trusted Third Parties
findings: LOW: Mathematical notation $-$\$100 and $+$\$100 used for balance changes; trivial but first math notation in the deck
MEDIUM: 'Atomic execution' is CS jargon; while parenthetical '(no partial transfers)' is given, the term may confuse non-CS students
MEDIUM: Flowchart uses math inequality symbol (Balance >= Amount?) which is accessible but approaches formal notation for a no-prerequisite deck

frame_title: The Cost of Trust: What We Gain
findings: MEDIUM: 'Chargebacks' is industry jargon used without definition; not all BSc students will know this term

frame_title: The Cost of Trust: What We Lose
findings: MEDIUM: 'Censorship' used in financial context without clarifying it means blocking transactions, not just media censorship
HIGH: Frame introduces 4 new financial terms (counterparty risk, insolvent, bank run, fractional reserve banking) plus the 2008 crisis context -- heavy for no-prerequisite students
MEDIUM: 'Insolvent' used without definition in the examples list
MEDIUM: Abbreviation 'TTP' (Trusted Third Party) used without prior definition in this frame; readers must infer from frame 16 title
MEDIUM: 'Byzantine Generals Problem' is CS-specific jargon; while the thought experiment explains it, the formal name may signal prerequisite CS knowledge to students
LOW: 'Consensus' used in technical sense without explicit definition

frame_title: From Generals to Money: The Same Problem
findings: LOW: 'Byzantine Generals Problem for large, open networks' assumes the previous frame was absorbed; good building, but cognitive load stacks
LOW: 'Instant settlement' and 'counterparty risk' reused from earlier frames without back-reference; fine if students recall
MEDIUM: Four historical projects named (DigiCash, e-gold, b-money, Bit Gold) with only single-word failure reasons; students have no context for why these matter
LOW: 'Byzantine consensus' used again without refresher
MEDIUM: 'Cryptography' introduced without definition; students promised no CS prerequisites may find this term opaque
LOW: 'Satoshi Nakamoto' name-dropped without explaining the pseudonymous nature
LOW: 'Colab notebook' may be unfamiliar to students who have never used Google Colab; a one-line explanation would help

frame_title: Discussion: Money in the Digital Age

findings: MEDIUM: 'Stablecoin' appears in the comparison table without any prior definition in T1.1; this is a topic from Day 4
LOW: Table uses terms (reversibility, censorship) whose financial meanings were defined earlier but may need column headers for clarity
MEDIUM: 'Remittances' used as section header without definition (defined later in T1.2 key terms but not here)
LOW: 'Hyperinflation' and 'capital controls' are economics terms used without definition
MEDIUM: 'CBDCs' abbreviation used; expanded below as 'Central bank digital currencies' but the abbreviation appears first
LOW: 'Stablecoins' and 'corporate tokens' mentioned without definition (forward references to Day 4)
LOW: Glossary defines terms that were used many frames earlier; consider placing definitions closer to first use
LOW: 'Atomic Execution' and 'Single Source of Truth' are CS terms; definitions are clear but the terms were introduced much earlier without this level of explanation
MEDIUM: 'Fiat' (as in 'fiat currency') used for the first time without prior definition; explained in-line but the term itself is financial jargon
MEDIUM: 'Cryptographic hashing', 'consensus mechanisms', and 'decentralization' are all technical terms previewed without definition; acceptable for a preview frame but stacks 3 new jargon items
MEDIUM: 'FinTech' and 'DeFi' used in Key Insight block without definition; these are jargon that no-prerequisite BSc students may not know
HIGH: Prerequisites list 'General knowledge of stock market trading' -- this violates the course promise of no finance prerequisites

frame_title: The Big Picture: Why Study Pain Points?
The Global Financial System: A Marvel of Complexity
findings: HIGH: Six institutional types (central banks, commercial banks, investment banks, payment networks, exchanges, clearinghouses) shown in a diagram without any definitions; a no-prerequisite student cannot distinguish commercial from investment banks or know what a clearinghouse does
MEDIUM: '$9.6 trillion daily' statistic given without source
MEDIUM: 'Settlement', 'opacity', and 'fragmentation' are used as friction labels without definitions; each will be explained later but students see all 6 terms at once
HIGH: Frame introduces T+1, ACH, SWIFT, correspondent bank, batch processing, and compliance checks -- more than 5 new terms for a no-prerequisite audience
MEDIUM: 'T+1' notation is financial jargon; parenthetical explanation helps but notation itself is opaque
LOW: Diagram shows 6-hop chain that may overwhelm without progressive reveal

prerequisite_knowledge: basic understanding of T+1 from previous frame
findings: HIGH: Adds Fedwire, clearing, and opportunity cost on top of the 6+ terms from the previous frame; cumulative jargon load is very high

MEDIUM: '$1 trillion locked in settlement = $50M+/day in opportunity cost (at 2% annual rate)' -- this is a math calculation that assumes students can verify the arithmetic and understand opportunity cost
HIGH: 'Counterparty risk', 'working capital', 'systemic risk', 'contagion risk' -- four finance-specific terms in one table, none defined here
MEDIUM: 'Lehman Brothers failure' reference assumes awareness of the 2008 crisis; no-prerequisite students born after 2005 may lack this context
MEDIUM: 'Remittance' used in body text without definition (defined much later in frame 33)
LOW: Bar chart is hand-drawn in TikZ; values are approximate and could be misread

frame_title: High Fees: Where Does Your Money Go?
findings: HIGH: Five jargon terms (SWIFT messaging, correspondent bank, FX spread, lifting fees, intermediary deductions) without definitions in this frame
MEDIUM: 'FX spread' assumes students know what FX means and what a spread is
LOW: 'Lifting fees' is obscure even for finance professionals and is completely undefined
MEDIUM: 'UN SDG target' -- 'SDG' abbreviation not expanded (Sustainable Development Goals); no-prerequisite students may not know this
LOW: 'Unbanked' and 'underbanked' are self-explanatory compound words; good accessibility
HIGH: Five finance-specific terms (information asymmetry, expense ratios, payment for order flow, interchange fees, pricing algorithms) introduced without definitions
MEDIUM: 'Payment for order flow' is a complex market-microstructure concept; no-prerequisite students have no frame of reference
HIGH: Table contains advanced financial jargon: 'soft dollars', 'yield spread premiums', 'PFOF' -- these are industry-insider terms inaccessible to no-prerequisite BSc students
MEDIUM: 'PFOF' abbreviation used in table without expansion (expanded only in a later frame title)

frame_title: Opacity Case Study: Payment for Order Flow
findings: CRITICAL: Frame assumes knowledge of stock market order execution (market makers, spreads, order routing) -- directly violates 'no finance prerequisites' promise
HIGH: Four market-microstructure terms (market maker, spread, order flow, execution prices) used without definitions; these are specialized even for finance students
MEDIUM: Diagram shows broker-market maker-market flow that requires understanding of how stock exchanges work
HIGH: Six payment system names (Visa, Mastercard, ACH, SWIFT, Fedwire, SEPA) shown as nodes without explaining what any of them do; assumes familiarity with payment infrastructure
MEDIUM: Incompatibility symbol (not-equal sign) between systems implies they should work together, but no explanation of what 'compatibility' means here

prerequisite_knowledge: SWIFT and correspondent banks from earlier frames
findings: LOW: Repeats the correspondent bank chain from frame 7; good reinforcement

CRITICAL: Technical standard names (NACHA, ISO 15022, ISO 20022) and a programming language (COBOL) shown without any explanation; this is IT/finance infrastructure jargon completely inaccessible to no-prerequisite students
HIGH: Protocol stack comparison diagram assumes understanding of layered system architecture
MEDIUM: 'T+1', 'T+2-5', 'Same Day' settlement labels reuse notation that may still be unclear

frame_title: Limited Hours: The Global Business Problem
findings: LOW: 'UTC' used in diagram axis labels without explanation; most BSc students know this but it is technically jargon

frame_title: Who Bears the Cost? A Summary
prerequisite_knowledge: all six frictions from earlier frames

MEDIUM: 'Crypto rails', 'neobanks', 'L2 networks' used without definitions; these are digital-finance insider terms

frame_title: Mapping Frictions to Digital Finance Solutions
findings: HIGH: Eight new proper nouns/terms (FedNow, UPI, M-Pesa, Plaid, Stripe, L2 networks, smart contracts, permissionless wallets) in a single table with no definitions
MEDIUM: Table format does not allow space for even brief explanations; students see a wall of unfamiliar names

LOW: 'Circuit breakers' and 'security through obscurity' are domain-specific terms used without definitions

LOW: 'FX markup' uses 'FX' abbreviation that may not be clear to all BSc students
LOW: Glossary at slide 33 defines terms that were used 20+ frames earlier (e.g., settlement, SWIFT, correspondent bank); consider moving definitions closer to first use

LOW: Question mentions 'ACH transfers' assuming students recall this from earlier; acceptable for self-assessment

frame_title: What's Next: Topic 1.3 - Digital Solutions Overview
findings: LOW: 'APIs' and 'open banking' previewed without definition; acceptable for a transition slide
LOW: 'BIS' abbreviation (Bank for International Settlements) used in reading list without expansion

frame_title: Prerequisites: Recap of Money and Finance

findings: HIGH: Cross-file inconsistency -- T1.2 names the six frictions as (1) Slow Settlement, (2) High Fees, (3) Exclusion, (4) Opacity, (5) Fragmentation, (6) Limited Hours, but this recap lists completely different categories: Information Asymmetry, Access & Inclusion, Transaction Costs, Trust & Counterparty Risk, Agency Problems, Regulatory Complexity. A student who just studied T1.2 will be confused by the mismatch.
MEDIUM: "Information asymmetry", "counterparty risk", and "agency problems" are economics jargon not previously defined in the course sequence
LOW: "Disintermediate incumbents" uses two terms a BSc student may not know; consider simpler phrasing such as "remove middlemen"
MEDIUM: "APIs and Open Banking" listed as key technology but not defined until T1.4/Day 2; students with no CS background may not understand what an API is
MEDIUM: FDIC insurance is US-specific and unexplained; international students may not know this term. Chargebacks likewise undefined.
LOW: The TikZ diagram uses "Card Network" node without explaining what card networks are
MEDIUM: 10 company names in one slide creates high brand density; students outside the US may not recognize most of them
MEDIUM: ACH, SWIFT, POS, and "mid-market FX rates" are all undefined jargon used in a single frame

HIGH: 9 company names (Chime, N26, Revolut, Nubank, Monzo, SoFi, Ally, LendingClub, Prosper) plus 4 more (Affirm, Klarna, Upstart, Kabbage) = 13 names in one frame, creating an overwhelming product dump

HIGH: 8 undefined jargon terms in a single frame (neobanks, chartered banks, P2P marketplace, BNPL, AI-based underwriting, SMB lending, alternative data, credit infrastructure); exceeds 5-term threshold
MEDIUM: "BNPL (Buy Now Pay Later)" is defined by acronym only, but the business model is not explained until T1.4
MEDIUM: 10 company names (Robinhood, Webull, Betterment, Wealthfront, Acorns, Stash, Public, M1 Finance, Lemonade, Oscar) in one frame; some students will disengage from a long name-list
LOW: "Telematics-based auto" insurance is niche jargon that is not explained

MEDIUM: 5 undefined technical terms (smart contracts, public-key cryptography, consensus mechanisms, distributed ledgers, permissionless access) introduced together; these are Day 3 topics being previewed without definition
LOW: The vending-machine analogy for DeFi is good but could be misunderstood since vending machines do not handle financial logic
LOW: "Cryptographic proofs verify transactions mathematically" is abstract for a no-math-prerequisite audience but the escrow analogy helps compensate
LOW: MetaMask, Uniswap, and Aave appear on the spectrum diagram without explanation; students who have not heard of these will not understand the right-hand side of the spectrum
HIGH: 12 named protocols/tokens (Bitcoin, Ethereum, Solana, USDC, USDT, DAI, FRAX, Polygon, Arbitrum, Optimism, zkSync) dumped in one frame with minimal explanation
HIGH: Layer 2 solutions, rollups, and zero-knowledge proofs are Day 3-4 topics (T3.5, T4.5) presented here on Day 1 with zero context; violates prerequisite constraint
MEDIUM: 10 undefined jargon terms in one frame far exceeds the cognitive load threshold for a no-prerequisite audience
HIGH: 7 undefined jargon terms (AMM, liquidity pools, order books, custodial, KYC, non-custodial, DEX aggregation) introduced in one frame; AMM and liquidity pools are Day 4 topics
MEDIUM: 8 company/protocol names in one slide (Uniswap, SushiSwap, Curve, dYdX, 0x, Coinbase, Binance, Kraken) adds to cognitive overload
MEDIUM: "Flash loans" and "algorithmic interest rates" are advanced DeFi concepts (Day 4) mentioned without explanation
MEDIUM: Over-collateralized and liquidation concepts are introduced in a bullet list without explanation of what collateral ratios mean

CRITICAL: Derivatives, synthetic assets, perpetual futures, and permissionless leverage are advanced financial concepts requiring substantial background in finance; presenting them to a no-finance-prerequisite BSc audience on Day 1 without definitions violates the course promise

HIGH: 10 undefined jargon terms in a single frame (derivatives, synthetic assets, perpetual futures, Virtual AMM, options protocol, permissionless leverage, oracles, indexing protocol, decentralized storage, naming service)

HIGH: 8 protocol names (Synthetix, GMX, Perp Protocol, Dopex, Chainlink, The Graph, IPFS, ENS) dumped without explanation; the frame tries to cover two distinct sub-sectors (derivatives AND infrastructure) at once
MEDIUM: "Virtual AMM derivatives" combines two unexplained concepts into a single bullet

frame_title: Permissioned vs. Permissionless: Why Does This Matter for YOU?
findings: LOW: Well-structured comparative frame with clear student-facing language; good use of checkmarks and crosses

frame_title: Concept Map: The Digital Finance Ecosystem

findings: MEDIUM: Definitions frame appears at slide 33; many terms here (AMM, BaaS, embedded finance) were used as early as slides 9-14 without definition. Moving definitions earlier or adding footnotes would help.
LOW: ERC-4337 mentioned in the Account Abstraction definition; this is highly technical for a Day 1 glossary frame
